awd_titl_txt: U-Pb Thermochronology of Lower Crustal Xenoliths: Estimating Moho Temperature in Order to Constrain Crustal Heat Production
awd_abstract_narration:
The energy that drives mantle convection and thus plate tectonics on Earth is a combination of heat remaining from Earth accretion, heat generated by crystallization of the inner core, and heat generated by radioactive decay of naturally occurring radioisotopes, primarily potassium (K), thorium (Th), and uranium (U), the heat-producing elements (HPE). All HPEs are strongly concentrated into the continental crust. Thus, documenting their concentrations in the crust is essential for any quantitative accounting of heat production within the deeper Earth, but such documentation has proven elusive. This project will seek to develop a method that can be used to quantify the budget of HPEs in the continental crust.

Because the continental crust is highly heterogeneous, and mostly inaccessible, determining the HPE abundances of the crust has often been attempted using surface heat flow data. However, the heat flowing from the Earth?s surface is a combination of heat produced within the crust and heat flowing from the underlying mantle and distinguishing between these two heat sources has been difficult. Our project seeks to determine crustal heat production by placing constraints on the temperature at the Moho - the boundary between the crust and the mantle. To do this, we will analyze minerals that, though widespread, occur in low abundances in most crustal rocks - termed accessory phases. Select accessory phases contain U when they crystallize, but exclude Pb (the ultimate daughter product of U decay). We will extract U-bearing accessory phases from samples of the lower crust that were carried rapidly to the surface in basaltic magmas (xenoliths). Because the temperature at which Pb diffuses in each of the accessory phases varies from one mineral species to the next, we can use the Pb isotope data to determine the temperature at which the xenoliths were sitting prior to their entrainment in the basaltic host lavas. Combined with estimates of the pressure of equilibration of the samples (hence, depth of derivation), and the surface heat flow, we can use our data to determine the HPE content of the continental crust in a given region. This project will serve as a demonstration of feasibility, which, if successful, can be applied to other regions in order to develop a HPE concentration map of the continents.

por.por_cntn:
The amount of heat generated in Earth is some combination of heat produced during planetary accretion, latent heat associated with the cooling of the liquid outer core, and radioactive decay. The latter provides the energy needed to drive convection within the mantle, which, in turn, drives plate tectonics. A significant portion of Earth’s radioactive (heating-producing) elements—such as U, Th and K—are sequestered in the continental crust, and are therefore not available to power mantle convection, but the exact amount of heat-producing elements contained within the continental crust has proven difficult to determine. Attempts to bracket crustal heat production include using seismic waves to infer temperature changes throughout Earth’s interior. However, seismic waves vary with rock composition, grain size, etc., in addition to temperature. We have used elemental diffusion—a dominantly thermal process—to relate deep crustal temperatures with the abundance of heat-producing elements of the continental crust. Xenoliths are rock samples erupted directly from great depths within the crust; diffusion experiments carried out on a multitude of elements in minerals common to xenoliths provide a way of determining the temperatures at which the xenoliths resided prior to their incorporation into the erupted basalt. Using this approach we were able to determine the present-day temperatures of the deep crust, which, when combined with measurements of the amount of heat escaping at the surface, provides a way of estimating how much of Earth's heat-producing elements are sequestered in the crust. We found that the crustal heat production in ancient regions of the continental interiors is quite low and is directly responsible for the low amount of heat observed to emanate from the surface in these regions. The project supported the PhD research of a first-generation Hispanic student, and provided hands-on research experiences to seven undergraduate students at UC Santa Barbara. The project increased diversity within Earth sciences, as three of the undergraduate students are Hispanic, four are female, and one was an international visiting scholar. Of these undergraduate students, six are pursing advanced degrees (two are applying to graduate programs, and four are currently enrolled in PhD programs at a variety of institutions); the seventh is gainfully employed in private industry.
